bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 4, 1940

div1.p: Hench contacts Kean to arrange a meeting. He also encloses a list of questions and comments and requests some addresses.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 4, 1940
div1.opener:
June 4, 1940
General J. R. Kean
2804 N Street N.W.
Georgetown
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
According to my present plans, I will be in New York, at the Waldorf-
Astoria Hotel, from Saturday, June 8, to Thursday afternoon, June 13. We will
then come to Washington, and I have arranged for reservations either at Hotel
Raleigh or the Mayflower. Unfortunately, for my interest in seeing you, I will
have my three children and wife with me, and will have to spend probably all of
Friday and Saturday with them. I will take them to Charlottesville on Sunday,
the sixteenth, and according to present plans, I am hoping to return without
them to Washington, to be free to see you on Monday, the seventeenth, if this
is agreeable. I will be bringing some material with me which I think will
interest you--material collected in Havana.

In the meantime, may I send you the enclosed list of questions and
comments. Same of them will not be clear to you until I have the privilege of
seeing you, but others may give you an idea of some of the questions that I
should like to find an answer for. I would appreciate hearing from you, if you
will address me at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York, to know whether it
will be possible for me to see you on the seventeenth. If not, I will try to
make some other arrangements and I can call you at least by phone on the fourteenth
to confirm the appointment. I will certainly try not to tire you or bother you
unduly or to presume too much on your time.

Do you, by chance, know the address of Mrs. Lazear, of Mrs. Reed, and
of her son? I am most anxious to get in touch with them.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
